Generation I.Red: During the day, it keeps its face buried in the ground. At night, it wanders around sowing its seeds.
Generation I.Green: (This entry was originally untranslated in English until it was reused in Pokémon FireRed .)
Generation I.Blue: During the day, it keeps its face buried in the ground. At night, it wanders around sowing its seeds.
Generation I.Yellow: It may be mistaken for a clump of weeds. If you try to yank it out of the ground, it shrieks horribly.
Generation I.Stadium: Burrows underground in the day, exposing only its leaves. It is said to scream loudly if anyone tries to yank it out.

Generation II.Gold: Awakened by moonlight, it roams actively at night. In the day, it stays quietly underground.
Generation II.Silver: If exposed to moonlight, it starts to move. It roams far and wide at night to scatter its seeds.
Generation II.Crystal: During the day, it stays in the cold underground to avoid the sun. It grows by bathing in moonlight.
Generation II.Stadium 2: Awakened by moonlight, it roams actively at night. In the day, it stays quietly underground. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) If exposed to moonlight, it starts to move. It roams far and wide at night to scatter its seeds. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: During the daytime, Oddish buries itself in soil to absorb nutrients from the ground using its entire body. The more fertile the soil, the glossier its leaves become.
Generation III.Sapphire: Oddish searches for fertile, nutrient-rich soil, then plants itself. During the daytime, while it is planted, this Pok é mon 's feet are thought to change shape and become similar to the roots of trees.
Generation III.Emerald: This Pok é mon grows by absorbing moonlight. During the daytime, it buries itself in the ground, leaving only its leaves exposed to avoid detection by its enemies.
Generation III.FireRed: Its scientific name is “Oddium Wanderus.” At night, it is said to walk nearly 1,000 feet on its two roots.
Generation III.LeafGreen: During the day, it keeps its face buried in the ground. At night, it wanders around sowing its seeds.

Generation IV.Diamond: It often plants its root feet in the ground during the day and sows seeds as it walks about at night.
Generation IV.Pearl: It often plants its root feet in the ground during the day and sows seeds as it walks about at night.
Generation IV.Platinum: It often plants its root feet in the ground during the day and sows seeds as it walks about at night.
Generation IV.HeartGold: Awakened by moonlight, it roams actively at night. In the day, it stays quietly underground.
Generation IV.SoulSilver: If exposed to moonlight, it starts to move. It roams far and wide at night to scatter its seeds.

Generation V.Black: It often plants its root feet in the ground during the day and sows seeds as it walks about at night.
Generation V.White: It often plants its root feet in the ground during the day and sows seeds as it walks about at night.
Generation V.Black 2: It often plants its root feet in the ground during the day and sows seeds as it walks about at night.
Generation V.White 2: It often plants its root feet in the ground during the day and sows seeds as it walks about at night.

Generation VI.X: During the day, it stays in the cold underground to avoid the sun. It grows by bathing in moonlight.
Generation VI.Y: Its scientific name is "Oddium Wanderus." At night, it is said to walk nearly 1,000 feet on its two roots.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: During the daytime, Oddish buries itself in soil to absorb nutrients from the ground using its entire body. The more fertile the soil, the glossier its leaves become.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: Oddish searches for fertile, nutrient-rich soil, then plants itself. During the daytime, while it is planted, this Pokémon's feet are thought to change shape and become similar to the roots of trees.

Generation VII.Let's Go Pikachu: It may be mistaken for a clump of weeds. If you try to yank it out of the ground, it shrieks horribly.
Generation VII.Let's Go Eevee: It may be mistaken for a clump of weeds. If you try to yank it out of the ground, it shrieks horribly.

Generation VIII.Sword: If exposed to moonlight, it starts to move. It roams far and wide at night to scatter its seeds.
Generation VIII.Shield: During the day, it stays in the cold underground to avoid the sun. It grows by bathing in moonlight.
Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: It often plants its root feet in the ground during the day and sows seeds as it walks about at night.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: It often plants its root feet in the ground during the day and sows seeds as it walks about at night.

Generation IX.Scarlet: Its scientific name is Oddium wanderus. It is said to cover distances as far as 1,000 feet when night falls, walking on its two roots.
Generation IX.Violet: When it is woken by moonlight, it wanders about. But during the day, it stays still underground.
